name: Lime
tagline: Help secure Lime

target_groups.name: Public In-Scope
target_groups.description_html:
All of the below targets are publicly accessible. Accounts can be provisioned where signup is available. Some of the targets will NOT have a user signup or registration process. This means it is for internal use only.

Lime Mobile Apps

Our mobile applications allow you to manage on the go. The apps are available on Android and iOS, they are a single codebase. Any issues found on backend logic in Android will also be on iOS, and vice versa. Submissions will be duplicated when submitting to either device.

Rider Application:

This is our primary customer-facing mobile application which riders use to ride Lime products. The application allows riders to manage their account, start/reserve rides, manage their Lime subscriptions, create support requests, and other tasks. The Android app uses Kotlin and Java and the iOS app uses Swift and Objective-C, powered by ruby on rails on the backend, running on Kubernetes cluster in AWS. Credentials can be provisioned in the user signup flow in the application

Supply Application (Supply One)

This is our primary operator-facing mobile application which operators use to perform operational tasks to keep the Lime fleet operational. The users of this application are Juicers and Logistical partners. The application allows operators to manage their account, perform out-of-warehouse tasks, manage their payment of how Lime pays them, provides a learning center of how to perform tasks, etc. The Android app uses Kotlin and Java and the iOS app uses Swift and Objective-C, powered by ruby on rails on the backend, running on the kubernetes cluster in AWS. Credentials can be provisioned in the user signup flow in the application.

Lime API testing

Web-production API (lime.bike)

This API is our primary backend API. It is a RESTful API. This acts as the brain of all Lime applications. These APIs serve all the features of Lime applications described above. This is developed in Ruby on Rails.

External API (lime.bike)

This API is our subset of backend APIs. It is a RESTful API. This endpoint serves Government relations requirements and Uber integration features. These APIs serves all the features of Admintool GR features and Uber app serving Lime riders. This is developed in Ruby on rails.

  • external-api.lime.bike = Uber integration API
  • Data.lime.bike = Government relations features API

Lime Bike communication

Proxy platform

This is a centralized and unified IoT Message communication between bikes and backend workflow. It is an independent and isolated IoT parser service to consolidates different types and formats of device messages into same format

  • web-message , web-message-high = Bike communication

target_groups.name: Private In-scope
target_groups.description_html:
All of the below targets are not publicly accessible. Accounts can be provisioned where signup is available. Some of the targets will NOT have a user signup or registration process. This means it is for internal use only.

Please DO NOT email Lime to create test accounts for these endpoints.

Lime Mobile Apps

Ops application (iOS only)

This is our operators' mobile application which operators use to perform operational tasks to maintain the Lime fleet. The users of this application are Operators(FTE) and Lime full-time employees(FTE). The application allows operators to manage their accounts, perform in-warehouse tasks, manage their payment of how Lime pays them, provide a learning center of how to perform tasks, etc. This app is only available on Lime company-owned devices and Lime FTE devices. iOS app uses Swift and Objective-C, powered by ruby on rails on the backend, running on the kubernetes cluster in AWS. Credentials CANNOT be provisioned in the application.

Lime Web Apps

Admintool Web application

This is our main management application which Lime employees use to configure settings of all three customer profiles. The users of this application are Lime full-time employees(FTE) and Government relations personnel of the Lime markets. The app uses Typescript and Javascript, powered by ruby on rails on the backend, running on Kubernetes cluster and served from an S3 bucket in AWS. Credentials CANNOT be provisioned at in the user signup flow of the application

LP dashboard web-application

This is our management application which logistical partners use to onboard contractors to the Supply One app. The users of this application are Logistical Partner power users. The application allows LPs to manage their contractors, assign out-of-warehouse tasks to contractors, manage their payment, see Live maps of tasks, performance insights, and task forecasting. The app uses Typescript and Javascript, powered by ruby on rails on the backend, running on Kubernetes cluster and served from an S3 bucket in AWS. Credentials CANNOT be provisioned in the user signup flow of the application

Data Portal

This is our data portal application which Lime full-time employees use to view data insights to power their decision making. The users of this application are Lime full-time employees. The application allows Lime employees to share custom dashboards, insights, and queries to corroborate their decision-making. The app uses Vue, typescript, javascript, CSS, and shell scripts. Credentials CANNOT be provisioned in the user signup flow of the application.

Inhouse deployment pipeline

The users of this application are Lime full-time employees(developers). The application allows us to manage deployments, jobs, migrations, and sandboxes at Lime. The app uses Python, HTML, Javascript, CSS, and shell scripts. Credentials CANNOT be provisioned in the user signup flow of the application.

Lime website

Website, though this is public but the main functionality resides on mobile applications. The users of this application are the general public. The application allows us to share information with the public. The app uses Twig, PHP, HTML, JavaScript, and CSS. Credentials CANNOT be provisioned in the user signup flow of the application.

Lime GPT

The users of this application are Lime full-time employees. The application allows us to use GPT-based AI methods for multiple applications including our internal knowledge chatbot, translations, feedback analysis, and photo verification. The app uses Python, streamlit, and OpenAI APIs. Credentials CANNOT be provisioned in the user signup flow of the application.

Lime API testing

  1. Help.lime.bike: FAQ for Lime applications help center
  2. ops.lime.bike = Ops application
  3. juicer.lime.bike = LP dashboard
  4. admintool.lime.bike = Admintool application

target_groups.name: Out of scope
target_groups.description_html:
All wildcard (*) operators endpoint means every other endpoint that is explicitly not mentioned In-scope is considered Out-of-Scope. For example *.lime.bike is mentioned in Out-of-scope but web-production.lime.bike and admintool.lime.bike is mentioned in In-scope. So all lime.bike endpoints that are not explicitly mentioned in-scope are out-of-scope.

The following findings are out of scope:

  1. Cookie flags on webview.lime.bike
  2. "secret" keys exposed in iOS/Android builds that we do not consider secret
  3. *.airflow.limeinternal.com [Legacy domain]
  4. help.li.me (report to zendesk)
  5. community.li.me (report to bevy)
  6. Attacks that require unauthorized access to users' clients (phones, browsers, etc)
  7. Zero-day vulnerabilities (CVEs being added to NVD or GHSA (Github security advisory) with a score of 9.5 or lower) that are less than 30 days old.
  8. Android debugging enabled
  9. Lime account MFA issues are out of scope at the present time
  10. WAF bypass
  11. Open redirects / Lack of security speedbump when leaving the site (no immediate credential leak)
  12. Internal IP address disclosure
  13. Accessible Non-sensitive files and directories (e.g. README.TXT, CHANGES.TXT, robots.txt, .gitignore, WSDL, pprof, etc.)
  14. Social engineering / phishing attacks
  15. Self XSS
  16. Text injection
  17. Email spoofing (including SPF, DKIM, DMARC, From: spoofing, and visually similar, and related issues)
  18. Descriptive error messages (e.g. stack traces, application or server errors, path disclosure)
  19. Fingerprinting/banner disclosure on common/public services
  20. Clickjacking and issues only exploitable through clickjacking
  21. CSRF issues that don't impact the integrity of an account (e.g. log-in or out, contact forms, and other publicly accessible forms)
  22. Lack of Secure and HTTPOnly cookie flags (critical systems may still be in scope)
  23. Lack of rate limiting
  24. Login or Forgot Password page brute force, account lockout not enforced, or insufficient password strength requirements
  25. HTTPS mixed content scripts
  26. Username/email enumeration by brute forcing/error messages (e.g. login/signup / forgotten password)
  27. Exceptional cases may still be in scope (e.g. ability to enumerate email addresses via incrementing a numeric parameter)
  28. Missing HTTP security headers
  29. TLS/SSL Issues, including BEAST BREACH, insecure renegotiation, bad cipher suite, expired certificates, etc.
  30. Denial of Service attacks
  31. Out-of-date software
  32. Use of a known-vulnerable component (exceptional cases, such as where you are able to provide proof of exploitation, may still be in scope)
  33. Physical attacks against Lime's Facilities / Property /Assets

target_groups.name: Atlassian Forge
target_groups.description_html:
Atlassian Forge is an app development platform designed to revolutionize how Atlassian cloud products are customized, extended, and integrated.

More information on the platform can be found here: https://developer.atlassian.com/platform/forge/

Due to the collaborative nature of Atlassian products, we are not interested in vulnerabilities surrounding enumeration and information gathering (being able to work effectively as a team is the purpose of our products). Instead, we're more interested in vulnerabilities that can have a direct impact to the Forge Platform. Below is a list of some of the vulnerability classes that we are seeking reports for:

  • Forge Platform
  • Execution environment
  • Sandbox escapes
  • Supporting GraphQL endpoints
  • Access Control Vulnerabilities (Insecure Direct Object Reference issues, etc)
  • Server-Side Request Forgery (SSRF)
  • Forge CLI - https://www.npmjs.com/package/@forge/cli
  • Deployments
  • Forge App Installation/Uninstallation flows
  • UI Kit Stored/Reflected Cross-site Scripting (XSS) specifically targeting default behaviors of UI Kit elements

targets.name: Any customer instance. Do not test customer instances or affect customer data. Customer cloud instances may be in the form of <customer>.atlassian.net or <customer>.jira.com. Test only your own instances.
Any repository that you are not an owner of - do not impact Atlassian customers in any way.
First and third party apps and plugins from the marketplace are excluded from this bounty but may be in scope for https://bugcrowd.com/atlassianapps
HipChat (inc. HipChat Data Center, HipChat Desktop, HipChat Mobile)
Stride (inc. Stride Video, Stride Desktop, Stride Mobile)

target_groups.name: Public Other Targets
target_groups.description_html:
If you find a security flaw on a target that is outside of the scope mentioned under 'Private' and 'Public' Target but clearly affects Mastercard, you can report it at ''Public Other'' Program.
Also, findings related to Mergers and Acquisitions (M&A) could be considered under ‘Public Others’ category.

Vendor based application URLs/3rd party URLs:

Any Partner Sites of Mastercard (e.g. www.mastercard-*.com) are mainly marketing based sites that are not part of the core Mastercard domains (.mastercard.com) and are managed by hosting vendor companies. Vulnerabilities on these assets will be awarded lower bounties:

P1 P2 P3 P4
$700 $300 $150 $50

The reward amount for submissions reported for any lower environment (such as stage, dev, test, sandbox, or UAT) of third-party developed (vendor) applications will be 50% of the standard amount mentioned in above table.

give.mastercard.com is a vendor based application and bounty payouts will be according to this table.

Pay-outs for Subdomain Takeover:

Pay-outs for Subdomain Takeover findings differ from the rewards listed above. Please review the severity and descriptions below before submitting a report.

Impact Severity Reward Description
High Impact Subdomain Takeover P2 $900 Awarded for domains and subdomains with reputational or technical risk. Also, for subdomains under a parent domain with reputational or technical risk, and access to sensitive data on that parent domain.
Basic Subdomain Takeover P3 $300 Awarded for domains and subdomains under a parent domain with reputational or technical risk, but without access to sensitive data on that parent domain.
Concession award P4 $100 Awarded for domains and subdomains that are owned by Mastercard and have no risks except publicity risk (which is inherent in ownership)

target_groups.description_html:
Target Information:

ClickHouse Cloud is our SaaS platform which provides users with a managed ClickHouse service with seamless scaling and serverless operations. ClickHouse Cloud consists of several components. The Control Plane web application allows users to manage user access, start/stop instances, monitor usage information and configure advanced features such as IP Filtering, Advanced Scaling etc. The Data Plane and its components manage and store customers’ ClickHouse services and data.

Documentation:

  • https://clickhou.se/bugcrowddocs

Special requirements and guidelines:

ClickHouse is updated regularly. Keep an eye out on their Security Policy page https://github.com/ClickHouse/ClickHouse/security/policy in order to ensure you are testing on a supported version.

  • Security researchers must ensure the registration email for their testing account is a bugcrowd email address ending with @bugcrowdninja.com. For more info regarding bugcrowdninja email addresses, see here.
  • If you find a vulnerability that exposes customer or employee personal information, stop testing and report the issue immediately.
  • If you find a vulnerability that allows you to gain shell access to our environment, stop testing and report the issue immediately.
  • Do not purposefully attempt to degrade systems or services during testing.
  • Only target your own account and do not attempt to access data from anyone else’s account that you do not explicitly own.

Reporting requirements:

Researchers must follow guidelines from Bugcrowd in reporting a security vulnerability and the report must describe the vulnerability in detail, where it was discovered, the steps to reproduce and, most importantly, the potential impact of exploitation.

targets.name: ClickHouse Cloud environment hosted by ClickHouse

target_groups.name: ClickHouse OSS target
target_groups.description_html:
Target Information:

The source code is written in C++. ClickHouse is an open-source column-oriented DBMS (columnar database management system) for online analytical processing (OLAP), which allows users to generate analytical reports using SQL queries in real-time. The main focus of the public program is the open source version of the ClickHouse platform available at https://github.com/ClickHouse/ClickHouse. The repository contains source code for both the ClickHouse server and client(s) components. The ClickHouse software binaries can be downloaded from https://clickhouse.com/.

Documentation:

  • https://clickhouse.com/docs/en/intro

Supported Versions:

ClickHouse is updated regularly. Keep an eye out on our Security Policy page https://github.com/ClickHouse/ClickHouse/security/policy in order to ensure you are testing on a supported version.

Reporting Requirements

  • Researchers must follow guidelines from Bugcrowd in reporting a security vulnerability. Due to the nature of this specific target, the following are additional requirements to be qualified for a bug bounty:
  • The report should contain a description of the error and step-by-step instructions for reproducing it.
  • The issue should be reproducible in the latest official release and the latest build from master.
  • Unmodified source code and binaries have to be used in reproducing scenarios.
  • The issue should not be already published. If the issue is already found by another researcher, it is not qualified for bug bounty program.
  • The issue should be reproducible on Linux, x86_64 platform and should not depend on the Linux kernel version, libc version and configuration of environment like DNS resolvers, SSL certificates, filesystem and block devices configuration, etc. It should not depend on hardware failures.
  • The issue should be reproducible without installation of additional software on the machines with clickhouse-server.
  • If the issue requires usage of features marked as experimental in the documentation or code or enabling experimental flags (settings, configurations), it is not qualified for the bug bounty program.
  • The issue should be reproducible with release builds from ClickHouse CI infrastructure. Debug and sanitized builds, builds with another compiler or compiler options are not qualified.
  • The issue should be related to the clickhouse-server component.

target_groups.name: Out of Scope
target_groups.description_html:
Important:

  • New support cases, Chat, Request new integration form and Share feedback form are no longer included in target scope as these actions can generate unnecessary noises for our support team.

  • Do not use vulnerability scanners on this program. The use of custom scripts and fuzzing tools on this program must be targeted, specific testing, and then only at less than five requests per second to reduce noise and minimize potential disruption for our customers.

    • Results from a static code analysis tool with no manual verification or a proof of concept.
    • A list of out-of-date dependencies - chances are we are aware of this and the team is making efforts to update them accordingly without introducing any breaking changes. If you think a particular vulnerability is severe and exploitable from the way it is implemented in the ClickHouse codebase, please provide a proof of concept.
    • Theoretical security issues.
    • Web vulnerabilities against the built-in “play” HTTP server with the default local setup and no real-world impact (e.g. clickjacking, CSRF, missing security headers, etc.)
    • Third party websites or systems hosted by non-ClickHouse entities that ClickHouse staff use
    • DoS / DDoS attacks that may cause disruption to our service
    • Payment processing (handled by a third party)
    • Social Engineering

Testing is only authorized on the targets listed as in scope. Any domain/property of ClickHouse not listed in the targets section is out of scope. This includes any/all subdomains not listed above. If you happen to identify a security vulnerability on a target that is not in scope, but it demonstrably belongs to ClickHouse, you can report it here. However, be aware that it is ineligible for rewards or points-based compensation.

tagline: Cloud Identity and Mobility Management Service

target_groups.name: Okta Privileged Access
target_groups.description_html:
Redeem Credentials

  • At the bottom of the program brief, click on "Get Credentials" to retrieve 2 sets of credentials.

DO THIS FIRST!

  • Change the email address associated with the provided users so that you can handle your own password resets
  • Create at least 2 other Super Admins in each ORG for resetting locked accounts and handling account problems.
  • Follow the steps to setup and enforce MFA on each Login under "Required MFA Configuration"

Accessing Okta Privileged Access

  • Go to the Admin Dashboard and Applications
  • Go to Browse App Catalog and search for Okta Privileged Access. You will be asked to provide a team name which you should put your org name so bugcrowd-pam-###
  • After creating the application, go to assignments and assign yourself to the application
  • The Okta Privileged Access chiclet should appear on your Enduser Dashboard. Click the application and you'll be redirected
  • For full functionality, go to Groups, create group, and assign all team roles and assign a user to the group

Documentation

  • Overview: https://help.okta.com/en-us/content/topics/privileged-access/pam-overview.htm
  • Set up Okta Privileged Access: https://help.okta.com/en-us/content/topics/privileged-access/pam-setup.htm

target_groups.name: Okta Workflows
target_groups.description_html:
Redeem Credentials

At the bottom of the program brief, click on "Get Credentials" to retrieve 2 sets of credentials.

Access

To access Okta Workflows, go to the Okta Admin Dashboard -> Workflow -> Workflows Console

Focus Areas

  • Focus Areas for Okta Workflows
  • Ability to perform SSRF with Flo cards
  • Ability to provision and deprovision Workflow orgs
  • Performing Flo actions across orgs
  • Viewing sensitive information across orgs

Out of Scope

Testing for Denial of Service issues and testing with any sort of automation is STRICTLY out of scope. This will result in an immediate removal from Okta Workflows and in some cases, the Okta bug bounty program.

target_groups.name: Okta Device Access
target_groups.description_html:
Redeem Credentials

  • At the bottom of the program brief, click on "Get Credentials" to retrieve 2 sets of credentials.

Okta Device Access extends IAM (Identity and Access Management) capabilities across devices and applications, increasing your org's security posture and protecting you from phishing attacks. Local device data is protected by the same Identity Provider that protects access to data and applications in the cloud.

Documentation

  • Okta Device Access Documentation
  • Desktop MFA for Windows
  • Desktop MFA for macOS
  • Desktop Password Sync for macOS

Downloads

Download Okta Verify for Windows & macOS

  • Desktop MFA is part of Okta Device Access, which uses Okta Verify for device registration and user authentication. In the Admin Console, go to Settings -> Downloads and download either Okta Verify for Windows (.exe) or Okta Verify for macOS

target_groups.name: Okta Support Portal (support.okta.com)

Focus Areas

  • Crafting an aura payload to view data such as first/last name, company name, and IDs will not be accepted. If you are able to view credentials, emails, phone numbers, etc. these will be reviewed and accepted at the sole discretion of Okta.
  • Tampering, manipulating, or deleting customer data is strictly out of scope and these tests should be conducted against your own test account.
  • Eligible reports will be awarded based on severity, to be determined by Okta in its sole discretion.

name: OpenAI
tagline: OpenAI is an AI research and deployment company. Our mission is to ensure that artificial general intelligence benefits all of humanity.

target_groups.name: API Targets
target_groups.description_html:
The following services and applications are in-scope:

  • The OpenAI APIs.
  • Public cloud resources or infrastructure involved in serving the OpenAI API, including:
    • cloud storage accounts (e.g., Azure data blobs).
    • cloud compute servers (e.g., Azure virtual machines).

As noted earlier, model safety and content issues are not eligible for reward in any of the categories.

target_groups.name: ChatGPT
target_groups.description_html:
ChatGPT is in scope, including ChatGPT Plus, logins, subscriptions, OpenAI-created plugins (e.g. Browsing, Code Interpreter), plugins you create yourself, and all other functionality.

NOTE: You are not authorized to conduct security testing on plugins created by other people.

Examples of things we are interested in:

  • Stored or Reflected XSS
  • CSRF
  • SQLi
  • Authentication Issues
  • Authorization Issues
  • Data Exposure
  • Payments issues
  • Methods to bypass cloudflare protection by sending traffic to endpoints that are not protected by cloudflare
  • Ability to run queries on pre-release or private models
  • OpenAI created plugins:
    • Browsing
    • Code Interpreter
  • Security issues with the plugin creation system:
    • Outputs which cause the browser application to crash
    • Credential security
    • OAuth
    • SSRF
    • Methods to cause the plugin service to make calls to unrelated domains from where the manifest was loaded

Note: if your account is approved to create plugins, you may create and test your own plugins, their functionality, and their interactions with ChatGPT. You may sign up for the waitlist, but OpenAI and bugcrowd cannot get you off the waitlist, do not ask. You may not perform security testing on plugins created by other people (e.g. Plugins in the plugin store).

For model related issues, please use the reporting channels discussed earlier.
Model issues are strictly out of scope and will not be rewarded.

target_groups.name: Third Party Corporate Targets
target_groups.description_html:
This target group consists of confidential OpenAI corporate information that may be exposed through third parties. Some examples of the types vendors which would qualify in this category include:

  • Google Workspace
  • Asana, Trello, Jira, Monday.com
  • Notion, Confluence, Evernote
  • Intercom, Hubspot, Zendesk
  • Stripe, Airbase, Navan
  • Mode, Charthop, Looker

You are not authorized to perform additional security testing against these companies. Testing is limited to looking for confidential OpenAI information while following all laws and applicable terms of service. These companies are examples, and OpenAI does not necessarily do business with them.

Reports with multiple documents that share a root cause may be paid out at higher rates. Individual documents will typically be accepted at P4 or P5, which does not qualify for a monetary reward. For documents that contain particularly sensitive information, the reward category may be increased on a case-by-case basis. This will be rare.

Corporate target submissions must include detailed information to help us understand your discovery process.

target_groups.name: OpenAI API Keys
target_groups.description_html:
API Key Security Initiative for OpenAI

Our customers occasionally post their API keys on the internet. We need your help to keep them safe. Once a month, we will rank all submissions and award a bonus through the Bugcrowd platform to the researcher with the most impactful submission. Only the first submission of a given key will be considered. As a note, we will reach out to researchers that qualify for the reward. If you do not hear from us, it is safe to assume you did not win the current month. Please do not reach out to the Bugcrowd support team around the processing of these keys

  1. IMPORTANT: DO NOT SEND KEYS THROUGH BUGCROWD. Please report found API keys using the OpenAI API Key Bug Bounty Submission Form. Submissions to Bugcrowd will be marked as out-of-scope and will result in a point deduction.
  2. Do not post or share OpenAI API keys online.
  3. Valid OpenAI API Keys have the following structure: sk-w48. Any submission that does not adhere to this format will be rejected.
  4. Additional Things to Avoid:
    • Please don't submit the same keys repeatedly.
    • Don't create keys just to submit them.
    • Don't submit keys one-by-one - we can handle them in bulk.
  5. Creating multiple accounts or generating many API keys for a single account is a violation of our terms. This may result in account suspension. Play nicely. We keep a close eye on everything. Make sure that you act responsibly.

Thank you for your assistance!

This form is temporary - we will create an API for this soon.

Submit all findings here:
OpenAI API Key Bug Bounty Submission

IMPORTANT

Do not submit API keys to bugcrowd. The submission will be marked as out of scope and you will lose points. You must submit through the form.

name: Verisign
tagline: Verisign

target_groups.name: In Scope Targets - Tier 1 Rewards
target_groups.description_html:
Rewards Guidelines

Verisign may consider a variety of factors when determining the bounty that a researcher should receive for reporting a vulnerability, consistent with the policies identified above. Generally, however, Verisign will follow separate payment scales for vulnerabilities identified with Verisign's DNS and related infrastructure, on the one hand, and Verisign's other in-scope targets, on the other hand. Rewards for qualifying bugs range from $100 to $10,000. The following table outlines the usual rewards chosen for the most common classes of bugs:

Vulnerability DNS and related infrastructure
Remote Code Execution $10,000
Logic flaw bugs leaking or bypassing significant security controls $5,000
SQL Injection $5,000
Stored Cross Site Scripting $2,500
Reflected Cross Site Scripting $1,250

target_groups.name: In Scope Targets - Tier 2 Rewards
target_groups.description_html:
Rewards Guidelines

Verisign may consider a variety of factors when determining the bounty that a researcher should receive for reporting a vulnerability, consistent with the policies identified above. Generally, however, Verisign will follow separate payment scales for vulnerabilities identified with Verisign's non DNS related infrastructure. Rewards for qualifying bugs range from $100 to $5000. The following table outlines the usual rewards chosen for the most common classes of bugs:

Vulnerability Non-DNS related infrastructure
Remote Code Execution $5,000
Bypass Security Controls/Logic Flaw $2,500
Unrestricted/Arbitrary file access $2,500
Stored Cross Site Scripting $1,500
XSS (Reflective vs Stored) $500 - $1,250

Target Information

SnapNames is a domain name auction site for previously registered domain names, providing a back-ordering technology.

Testing Hours

All testing should be limited to OUTSIDE the hours of 12:00PM -7:00PM EST Monday through Friday. Testing is NOT PERMITTED during these hours as it will disrupt business operations.

Testing Headers

Please include the following headers in all server requests. This will not affect the responses to your activity, but allows Web.com to identify Researcher testing activity and avoid IP blocking.

Required
X-Request-Purpose: Research

Optional
`X-Bugcrowd-Ninja: [username]

Report Formatting

In the Description of a Vulnerability Report, please format the replication process as an Ordered List. Valid reports, formatted the following way, will be prioritized and accepted faster by Newfold Digital:

Steps To Reproduce: (Add details for how we can reproduce the issue)

  1. [add step 1]
  2. [add step 2]
  3. [add step 3]...

target_groups.name: Non-Circumvention Controls Targets
target_groups.description_html:
Scope Description

  • For this scope, we're inviting researchers to test our existing User Agreement Non-Circumvention Controls on our Marketplace and mobile iOS/Android/Desktop apps, as well as help us to discover unknown loopholes that can be exploited to gain directs access or share contact information. Our goal is to ensure that our clients and freelancers are using our platform in compliance with User Agreement Section 7 specifically.

Special Bonuses and Rewards

  • Ongoing and until we reward $10000 total for all submissions reported under this sub-program. We may extend this program in the future based on results.
    • Momentum Bonus, the more you submit, the more you earn!
    • There is a 7-day sliding window where you can build momentum on your rewards for this program, going forward, submissions made within the 7-day sliding window will be sorted by the severity assigned and the momentum bonus will be applied from highest to lowest severity, for example if you submit 3 bugs in this sequence [P3, P2, P1] within a 7 day sliding window, the submissions will be sorted by severity [P1, P2, P3] and the first (Bug with P1 Severity) pays 100%, the second (Bug with P2 Severity) pays 110%, the third (Bug with P3 Severity) pays 120%, etc. This scales to a maximum payout amount of 200% (double reward) the original value.

Disclosure Terms

  • This program has a coordinated disclosure policy. Disclosure requests will be reviewed on a case-by-case basis.

target_groups.name: Out of Scope
target_groups.description_html:
• All already known loopholes and planned remediation will not be rewarded.
  • Brute Forcing credentials to break into accounts is outside of scope.
  • The use of Social Engineering is out of scope.
  • Soliciting circumvention as a means of root cause identification.
  • Finding direct contact information through externally posted sources by either client or freelancer is out of scope unless this information is clearly linked from within the Upwork Marketplace and was not known to Upwork trust and safety teams already.

name: Kiteworks
tagline: Help Secure Kiteworks

target_groups.name: In Scope Targets
target_groups.description_html:
Focus Areas:

Kiteworks will give special consideration for the ability to exploit the following vulnerabilities: Unauthenticated Remote Code Execution (RCE) + Local Privilege Escalation (LPE) to Root user.

Submissions in this category if they meet the below specifications could be eligible for a $50,000 bounty. The guidelines for consideration for this reward are as follows:

  • Researchers need to be able to exploit both vulnerabilities: Unauthenticated Remote Code Execution (RCE) leading to Local Privilege Escalation (LPE) to Root user
  • These vulnerabilities must have a CVSS Score of 9-10.
  • Similar to any other submissions, please note that the CVSS Score for each submission may be changed upon further review and analysis.
  • These vulnerabilities must be found within any of the Kiteworks instances that have been listed as in-scope.

Additionally, while the Kiteworks application is hardened and requires advanced skills to exploit, there are still avenues to find vulnerabilities on the following focus areas outlined within the resources section. Vulnerabilities on these focus areas are eligible for rewards of $11,000 for P1s, $5,000 for P2s, $600 for P3s and $250 for P4s.

  • Unauthorized Access to Messages, Files and Folders
  • Uploading/Downloading endpoints
  • Incorrect Permissions
  • Bypassing Folder Roles Access Control
  • Previewer/Viewer
  • Injection attacks (SQL injections, XSS)
  • User REST endpoints
  • Remote Code Execution

To ensure a property is listed on a particular website use the registration link on that website. A new account requires both the email address and the mobile number to be verified before properties can be published. The email address can be validated by clicking a link in the email sent. To verify the mobile number do either of the following:

  • Register using the test number above and email bugcrowd-tavr@tripadvisor.com with the details of your account to get the test number verified.
  • Register a real mobile number and enter the code sent via SMS when prompted.

Once you have completed all the tests you wanted to execute against a test property, please disable that test property in order for it not show up anymore on the websites! We reserve the right to disable test properties if they do not meet the guideline or have been live for a while.

IMPORTANT: If you want your properties to be distributed to vacationhomerentals.com, you will need to request that explicitly. To do so, email bugcrowd-tavr@tripadvisor.com with the subject "Request to switch owner to VHR" and provide your owner ID. Once you submit the request allow up to a day for your property to appear in VHR listings

target_groups.name: Bokun
target_groups.description_html:
Access and Guidelines

Note that submissions for Bokun section are rewarded with points only, they are not eligible for bounties.

Accounts

You must be using “vulnscan” prefix in your vendor/supplier name when registering for an account for both types of scans (manual and/or automatic). Do not create an excessive number of accounts. Two accounts should be enough for testing the marketplace whereas a single account should be enough for any other intent or purpose.

Types of scans

Please focus on manual testing rather than using automated tools as the latter are already employed. Nevertheless, if you choose to ignore this advice and use automated tools, you must ensure the request rate to our systems does not exceed a 1 request per second. On top of that, we would also kindly ask you to use a HTTP Agent header which identifies such requests.

Email us in advance (vulnerabilities@bokun.io) if you will be using an automated tool. Our working hours are mostly those in the UTC time zone.

It is strictly forbidden to run automated or manual vulnerability testing on production systems (listed in "Out of scope" section below).

Information on systems in scope

Alias to this environment is “test”. Both external domains are just synonyms to the same service. There should be no difference between using either of them.

Our test environment, hosted at extranet.bokuntest.com has virtually identical setup as prod component-wise. We use this environment to experiment with near-prod-ready code branches which are otherwise hard to simulate on local environments as well as for general test reasons. Note that this environment is also used by some of our customers which are businesses experimenting with API integrations and/or trying out our system in some other ways. Making changes to certain system elements might be visible for those customers (e.g. via Marketplace) and therefore we insist on following rules:

  • Do not create an infinite amount of certain entities, e.g. vendor accounts. If you managed to find a gap where such entities are allowed to be created without reasonable limit, you must stop early and let us know
  • Some of these entities are displayed for our customers in certain contexts. Refrain from profanity or other offensive language
  • If you want to test illegal data access between different multi-tenant accounts (IDOR etc) please create accounts on your own without harnessing existing accounts

Our system exposes the ability to have embeddable widgets. Widgets are publicly accessible resources and are made accessible via widget.bokuntest.com.
Similar to this, we provide a public RESTful API via api.bokuntest.com. We’re happy to work with you in providing more details for how to create relevant entities and access these both endpoints. Alternatively, consult our helpdesk page as creating widgets / using API should hopefully not be too complicated.

target_groups.name: Segment Targets
target_groups.description_html:
NOTE: Sign up for Segment using your @bugcrowdninja.com email addresses, otherwise your accounts might be banned when we notice bad behavior

Area of Focus - $7,000

Segment cares deeply about our customers and their data. Security issues that allow unauthorized access without interaction to another workspace's event data, API keys, passwords, or other data deemed highly sensitive by Segment will be be given a "P0" reward of $7,000.

Access & Testing

  • Sign up for Segment using your @bugcrowdninja.com email addresses
  • Use Bugcrowd in your workspace names
  • Only test against accounts you have created
  • Limit your use of scanner tests based on our technology stack. Our application is primarily powered by Node.js, React, and GraphQL.

To test Segment you'll need to create a variety of data sources/destinations. We would recommend using those that have a bug bounty program such as Intercom, Twilio, Facebook, or Google. Services like Heroku can be valuable for creating resources such as Postgres instances to test our warehouses products.

Libraries

Segment provides libraries written in various languages to our customers (https://segment.com/docs/sources/). We invite you to review the source code of our Website, Mobile, and Server Libraries, all of which are hosted on Github. Qualifying submissions must have a demonstrable impact and realistic attack vector. Submissions that include a proposed fix will be easier for us to evaluate and reward.

Note on Trello Third Party Powerups

Trello Third Party Powerups are not officially under Atlassian ownership and do not follow the normal bug bounty security assessments. However, we may consider rewards for vulnerabilities found in Trello Third Party Powerups on a case by case basis if the vulnerability can affect Trello customers outside of the third party powerup (e.g. a valid XSS attack that can steal the Trello token of victim users).

The amount of the reward is based on the usage of the powerup and severity of the report and is much lower than the typical Trello reward. We typically reward only valid High and Critical (P2 and P1) severity reports.

Atlassian holds the right to eliminate rewards for third party powerups at any given time.

Important

As a company operating in a highly regulated sector, we need to take our responsibility to our user base very seriously. This means that we are required to have specific conditions in place, even for researchers testing on our platform. We understand that this may be frustrating, but please know that it is necessary for us to maintain compliance.
This means the following for you as a researcher:

  • When you first log into our platform, you will have access to a limited range of testing features. However, once you verify, you will have access to all features.
  • To make the verification process as smooth as possible, we can only accept certain documents from the countries listed here. Please refer to our website for a list of accepted documents. Thank you for your understanding and cooperation.

• Scanning should be limited to 2 requests per second

target_groups.description_html:
By way of clarification, the following is additional information on some of the domains that are in scope, and details around how they are used:

  • *.ikarem.io: This domain is used for Meraki internal services, and as such, falls under the higher reward range.
  • *.meraki.com: This domain is for the Cisco Meraki Dashboard and its integrated services.
  • *.network-auth.com: This domain hosts user-created content for Dashboard-configured splash pages.

Further public documentation can be found at https://documentation.meraki.com.

Additionally, documentation for the Cisco Meraki Dashboard API can be found at https://create.meraki.io/api-docs/.

It's further worth noting that:

  • Most products run a light web server which offers the ability to locally configure the uplink of a device, as well as to see some very basic device status information. However, the Dashboard is the ultimate administrative interface for devices, as well as the primary source for device monitoring.

  • This is touched on in the focus areas section, but any way of obtaining shell access on a Meraki device is an interesting finding to our team — as there should be no way for a user to meaningfully authenticate to a device.

  • In regards to obtaining firmware images, users may configure, via the Dashboard, a firmware version for a device to run and the device will automatically download and install the new version. More information on that can be found in our firmware FAQ.

target_groups.name: Tier 1 Targets - Hardware
target_groups.description_html:
Eligibility for Meraki Hardware

In an effort to increase testing accessibility on Meraki's physical products, Meraki manages a merit-based program to ship devices to eligible program participants. You can find the details of this program in the Announcement section of the Bounty Brief.

Hardware Notes

  • This is touched on in the focus areas section, but any way of obtaining shell access on a Meraki device is an interesting finding to our team — as there should be no way for a user to meaningfully authenticate to a device.

  • In regards to obtaining firmware images, users may configure, via the Dashboard, a firmware version for a device to run and the device will automatically download and install the new version. More information on that can be found in our firmware FAQ.

name: Tesla
tagline: Accelerating the world’s transition to sustainable energy

target_groups.name: Vehicle Targets

targets.name: Tesla vehicle hardware that you own

target_groups.description_html:
Payout Guidelines

The following section shows the range of payouts along with specific examples of impact. Within a category, the amount will depend on factors such as how much owner interaction is required, the capabilities of a compromised process (in the case of code execution), and the quality of the report.

The below examples are not meant to be an exhaustive list of all valid findings within the program, but are meant to provide some clearer high-level guidelines and inspiration to researchers. If you have a security issue to report to us that does not fall into the below categories, please do not hesitate to reach out to us with your findings. We will continue to update the table with relevant categories and their associated payouts.

If a vulnerability falls into multiple categories, the highest severity applies.

Critical ($50,000 - $100,000)

  • Remote zero-click to unconfined root on infotainment
  • Any remote code execution on a CAN-connected ECU, e.g. Autopilot, VCSEC, Gateway
  • Infotainment pivot to CAN-connected ECU, e.g. Autopilot, VCSEC, Gateway

High ($20,000 - $50,000)

  • Remote one-click to unconfined root on infotainment
  • Unconfined root persistence on infotainment or Autopilot
  • Remote zero-click on lower-privileged peripherals (WiFi/BT firmware, baseband)
  • Local privilege escalation from unprivileged process

Moderate ($10,000 - $20,000)

  • Unprivileged remote code execution on infotainment
  • Unconfined root on infotainment or Autopilot via ethernet
  • Unconfined root on infotainment or Autopilot via USB
  • Zero-click radio module remote code execution
  • Steam VM escape

Low ($500 - $10,000)

  • Unprivileged persistence on infotainment or Autopilot
  • Local drive authentication bypass
  • PIN-to-Drive bypass

We do not award bounties for:

  • Relay attacks
  • Hardware-based glitching and side-channel attacks
  • Confusing Autopilot by modifying the environment, such as adding lines to the road (CWE-XKCD-1958 attacks)
  • Tesla-specific known issues (e.g., publicly reported or previously reported by another researcher)
  • Chromium and/or Webkit bugs, unless chained with a full sandbox escape
  • Persistence and/or secure boot bypasses on Tegra-based infotainment systems
  • Attacks that require physical access on Tegra-based infotainment systems

Payout Factors

  • If a vulnerability affects multiple systems, e.g. shared code, bounty will be determined by the highest single amount with a bonus determined at Tesla's discretion
  • The bounty amount may be reduced if the attack is unreliable, relies on unusual conditions being met, etc.
  • A working proof-of-concept will help ensure you receive the maximum applicable payout for your report
  • Internal duplicates that are not yet fixed will still be rewarded at a reduced amount
  • Vulnerabilities affecting Tegra-based infotainment systems are rewarded at Tesla's discretion, along with a reduced payout
  • Superchargers and related infrastructure are out of scope

We may at our discretion award payouts for CVEs in third-party code that affect us, provided it's an unknown risk and the report demonstrates impact.

Root access program

To promote further security research, Tesla offers security researchers the opportunity to retain root access on their infotainment system even after their reported vulnerability has been patched. In order to qualify, a researcher must send in a valid report describing a novel way to gain root access on a Tesla infotainment system. Upon confirmation, Tesla will instruct the researcher on how to use their existing root access to enable the researcher SSH feature, along with an SSH certificate for the researcher's public key (tailored to their specific hardware ID). The certificate restricts SSH access to the local diagnostic ethernet link. Tesla may renew the certificate as long as the researcher continues reporting vulnerabilities.

target_groups.description_html:
Aiven for Apache Cassandra managed and hosted service:

See https://aiven.io/cassandra for details about the service.

Aiven for Apache Cassandra® is a fully managed NoSQL database, deployable in the cloud of your choice. Snap it into your existing workflows with the click of a button, automate away the mundane tasks, and focus on building your core apps.

Aiven for Dragonfly managed and hosted service:

See https://aiven.io/dragonfly for details about the service.

Aiven for Dragonfly is an in-memory database intended as an alternative to Redis.

Aiven for Apache Flink managed and hosted service:

See https://aiven.io/flink for details about the service.

Apache Flink is a framework and distributed processing engine for stateful computations over unbounded and bounded data streams. It is a perfect companion to Apache Kafka event streaming platform, to perform reliable and scalable real-time filtering, enriching, aggregating, alerting and analyzing of the events.

Aiven for Clickhouse managed and hosted service:

See https://aiven.io/clickhouse for details about the service.

Aiven for ClickHouse is powered by ClickHouse, a highly scalable, open source database that uses a column-oriented structure.

ClickHouse is designed for online analytical processing (OLAP) applications, and is an ideal tool for applications such as web analytics, or complex data reporting.

Aiven for Thanos Metrics managed and hosted service:

See https://aiven.io/docs/products/metrics/concepts/metrics-overview for details about the service.

Aiven for Thanos Metrics is a managed service that provides a Prometheus service for storing and querying service metrics information.

Aiven for Valkey managed and hosted service:

See https://aiven.io/valkey for details about the service.

Aiven for Valkey is an in-memory database using the open-source project https://valkey.io/. It is often used for queueing and caching, and is an alternative to Redis.

target_groups.name: In Scope (Website console)
target_groups.description_html:
Target Information:

Please be aware of the following two key points regarding console.aiven.io, to avoid spending your time on an informational or unreproducible submission:

  • API operations invoked by the console are authenticated using the aivenv1 token in the Authorization: header, not the browser cookies; if you copy the authorization header from a request made by a user, the operation will be performed as that user and this is not a bug.
  • The primary purpose of the Aiven console is for our customers to administer their services with us. Users can, and nearly all users do, grant credentials and access to services that they create to principals that may not even have a user in the Aiven console.

Note also that https://aiven.io is hosted by fly.io. We are aware that fly.io has a network configuration that makes some scanners claim ports are open which are not. Also, vulnerabilities that would affect any fly.io site should be reported to fly.io and not to this program. We are particularly interested only in those vulnerabilities in https://aiven.io that can affect https://console.aiven.io or https://api.aiven.io, or that allow for defacement or code injection into https://aiven.io.

If a repository is forked from another repository, and the vulnerability is also present in the repository it's forked from, it is not eligible for a bounty; we recommend submitting to upstream.

target_groups.name: Capture the Flag Challenge
target_groups.description_html:
Include in your report the following items:

  1. The complete contents of /etc/ssh/ssh_host_ed25519_key, i.e. the server's SSH host private ed25519 key, current as at the time of exploitation
  2. The current external IP address of the host
  3. An explanation of how you got the key

Please do not submit the server's public key or your own machine's SSH private key.

target_groups.name: Guild of Guardians
target_groups.description_html:
Guild of Guardians (GoG) is our flagship Web3 game. It runs on mobile and desktop, and uses our product Passport (see below) to sign gamers in. The backend is written in Java and uses gRPC and HTTP underneath for networking.

Note that Mineloader company assets are strictly out of scope. Only those assets that belong to Immutable and are linked to in the game client are in scope. Do not test against Mineloader infrastructure. If you're not sure -- please stop testing and ask Bugcrowd.

Guild of Guardians may not be available in all countries at the same time. You are always able to test it if you use Australian, Canadian or Indonesian IP space though. Guild of Guardians may not be available in all countries at the same time. You are always able to test it if you use Australian, Canadian or Indonesian IP space though.

The game is currently available in the AppStore in those regions: https://apps.apple.com/au/app/guild-of-guardians/id1574135647 . Google Play release is coming May 15, 2024, and you can pre-register here: https://play.google.com/store/apps/details?id=com.immutable.guildofguardians&hl=en&gl=US

target_groups.name: Passport
target_groups.description_html:
Passport

Games on Immutable use Passport. Immutable Passport is a non-custodial wallet and authentication solution that streamlines user onboarding through passwordless sign-on and automated wallet creation. Watch our talk about Passport and the Immutable ecosystem as it will greatly help you grasp the overall architecture and threat models that are important to us.

As a Web3 wallet, it lets one view NFT collections, trade, track assets, etc., but also lets one sign in to games and marketplaces. The Passport wallet is an SPA written in Typescript and uses Magic underneath for key generation and key management, while Passport’s on-chain contracts are deployed by https://github.com/immutable/wallet-contracts. The wallet traditionally allows buying/selling assets, signing/approving transactions, displaying assets at passport.immutable.com (and soon, transaction history).

When shipped as an SDK, Immutable Passport is an Open ID provider and uses the Open ID Connect protocol for authentication and authorization. Games and marketplaces can integrate Passport into their platforms to authenticate users and access their wallets via approved oAuth scopes.

All authentication on auth.immutable.com is handled by Auth0.

The most potent issues that can be discovered in Passport relate to key generation and use. XSS can also be potent if it lets attackers transact on behalf of the wallet user. The following properties must always hold true for a secure Passport, otherwise there is a vulnerability present:

  1. When email is used to sign in to Passport, only that email is associated with a single account, and only that account is associated with a Passport wallet.
  2. During social SSO (e.g. Google), if there is an email already registered with Passport, the two accounts will be merged.
    • The email match must be exact. E.g. a John.Doe+web3@bugcrowdninja.com is not the same as john.doe@bugcrowdninja.com, including capitalization.
  3. A single account with Auth0 is a single account with Passport, which in turn, maps into a single Smart Contract Wallet (SCW) contract on the zkEVM chain. The Magic private key created during Passport account creation can only operate on that SCW contract and only that Magic key.
  4. Only the owner of the wallet can send/sign transactions from that wallet, before giving approval to any other third party to transact on their behalf.
  5. Only the transaction contained on the confirmation screen will ever be sent to the chain.
  6. For pre-authorized transactions, it is not possible to breach the pre-agreed maximum transfer (“approved”) limit or any other limits contractually. 1.No transactions can be sent without Immutable’s smart contract wallet signer co-signing (by Relayer).
  7. Guardian modal is always used when confirming transactions in Passport.
  8. A user is always able to link any EIP-1193 compatible Web3 wallet (e.g. Metamask) they have access to, to their Passport.
  9. One user can not deny service to another user or render their Passport unusable, including denial of service when acquiring assets.
  10. The asset that a user is buying in Passport is exactly that asset on the chain.

Additionally, Passport employs the help of neighboring services that play critical role in its threat model:

  1. Guardian
    • A modal pop-up that is shown to a user for transaction confirmation. It is meant to protect users by showing an additional confirmation popup that they have to click on.
  2. Relayer
    • Co-signs Passport activities on-chain with Immutable’s signing key. This double signature from a user and Immutable can be checked on the chain.
  3. Developer Hub
    • OpenID clients are created in the Developer Hub. Create your own to start testing today!

target_groups.name: Developer Hub
target_groups.description_html:
Developer Hub

The Immutable DevHub empowers you to launch and manage your projects in one easy place. One can launch collections, analyze performance, tune access management and set up Passport. The Hub is another crucial part of our infrastructure as game studios use it to set up Passport.

While a vulnerability in the Passport will likely affect only a single user at a time, one in the Hub may impact e.g. all gamers of a single game studio. Developer Hub features many tools: Passport OpenID, chain monitoring with webhooks, contract deployment, etc. and is thus full of attack surface. The webhooks functionality uses Amazon’s SNS underneath. The most impactful vulnerabilities in the Hub are:

  • Broken access control through the Organizations feature. E.g. getting oneself added to any organization gets them access to the organization’s settings.
    • There are only two roles: Owner and Member. The only difference right now is that an Owner can remove organization members.
  • IDOR among accounts, organizations, etc. and horizontal privilege escalation
  • SSRF in the Hub can impact our Kubernetes cluster.
  • XSS - can change settings for a lot of Passport clients in one go.

target_groups.name: Immutable
target_groups.description_html:
Data Classification

In the following table, the types of sensitive information are classified into four categories: Restricted, Confidential, Internal Only, and Public. For any Security Reports, we will likely evaluate the impact based on the data classification. Any Public Data should have little Security Impact hence will likely be Out of Scope.

Classification Types Description Examples
Restricted Personal Identifiable Information (PII) Information that can be used to identify an individual Name, address, phone number, email, Social Security Number (SSN)
Restricted Authentication Credentials Information used to authenticate a user's identity Game Credentials, Crypto Private keys
Confidential Financial Information Information related to financial transactions Credit card number, bank account number
Confidential Chat/Conversation Data Messages exchanged between players during gameplay Chat logs, private messages
Public Cryptocurrency Wallet Address Publicly available address used for transactions Ethereum wallet address, Bitcoin wallet address
Public In-Game Purchases Transactional data related to in-game purchases NFT purchases, virtual currency purchases

targets.name: Anything that does not belong to Immutable
Any data exposure bug that are classified as Public Data such as Ethereum Wallet Address, NFT Purchase activity, or other public blockchain activity.

name: Skyscanner
tagline: We’re the travel company who puts you first. All the flight, hotel and car hire options you need, all in one place.  We are offering $100 - $8000 per vulnerability.

target_groups.name: AI Bias Testing
target_groups.description_html:
Overview

Our mobile application offers a unique feature for travelers to receive recommendations and destinations based on their specific queries. This functionality is powered by an instance of OpenAI, which processes user requests and provides appropriate location suggestions. The recommendations are limited to locations where we operate and are only available to users in English-speaking markets.

Functionality Description

  1. User Query Submission:
    Users can submit queries asking for travel recommendations.
    Example Query: "I would like to make a gastronomic travel."

  2. Response Generation:
    The OpenAI instance processes the query and responds with a list of valid destinations.
    Example Output:

    • Paris
    • Tokyo
    • Rome

  3. Market Limitation:

    • This feature is only accessible in English-speaking markets.
    • Recommendations are restricted to locations where our services are available.

Scope of Testing

  • Verify that the functionality accurately processes user queries and returns appropriate destination recommendations.
  • Confirm that the feature is only accessible to users in English-speaking markets.
  • Verify that is not possible to perform attacks like prompt injection, data poisoning, etc

Exclusions

  • Internal information is not shared via this feature; therefore, the risk of data leakage is low.
  • Testing should focus on the accuracy and validity of the recommendations rather than backend vulnerabilities, given the nature of the feature.
  • Any other feature of the mobile application is out of the scope.

Reporting Guidelines

  • Clearly describe the steps to reproduce any issues found.
  • Provide screenshots or recordings where possible to illustrate the issue.
  • Ensure that any reported issues are within the scope of the described functionality.

Reward Criteria

  • Valid issues related to incorrect recommendations or access limitations will be considered for rewards.
  • Out-of-scope issues, such as backend vulnerabilities unrelated to the described functionality, will not be eligible for rewards.

Example Query for Testing

Query: "I would like to explore historical sites."
Expected Output: (Example)

  • Athens
  • Cairo
  • Beijing

By following these instructions, you can effectively test the travel recommendation functionality in our mobile application and contribute to improving its accuracy and reliability.

targets.name: Any domain, property, product, protocol, or service of the app/hardware/software version not explicitly listed in the In-Scope section is out of scope; submissions are welcome but not guaranteed for the bounty/bonus.

target_groups.description_html:
WEB APPLICATIONS

  • Clickjacking on pages with no sensitive data or actions.
  • Unauthenticated/logout/logon Cross Site Request Forgery (CSRF).
  • Attacks requiring Man-in-the-Middle or physical access to a user’s device.
  • Previously known vulnerable libraries without a working Proof of Concept.
  • Use of outdated software/library version(s).
  • Comma Separated Values (CSV) Injection without demonstrating a vulnerability.
  • Any activity that could lead to disruption of our service (DoS, DDoS).
  • OPTIONS / TRACE HTTP method enabled.
  • Missing best practices in SSL/TLS configuration.
  • Expired SSL Certificates
  • Content spoofing and text injection issues without showing an attack vector/without being able to modify HTML/CSS.
  • Cookies that lack HTTP Only or Secure settings for non-sensitive data.
  • Attacks dependent upon social engineering of employees or vendors.
  • Presence of autocomplete functionality in form fields.
  • Lack of email address verification during account registration.
  • Missing security headers.
  • Mixed content issues.
  • Tabnabbing.
  • Reports of credentials exposed by other data breaches/known credential list.

MOBILE APPLICATIONS

  • Absence of certificate pinning, lack of obfuscation, jailbreak detection.
  • Android and iOS operating systems vulnerabilities.
  • Attacks targeting jailbroken or rooted mobile devices.
  • Automated scanning tools are out of scope for this program.
    • We’re not interested in the issues straight from the automated scanners – demonstrate the exploitability to qualify for the bounty/bonus.
  • Memory dumps or issues found by tools that read active or cached memory.
    • Attacks would require an already compromised system and a malicious actor with escalated privileges. Once such an attack can be performed on a system, there is no way in principle to protect other processes running on that system.

Target Information:

target_groups.name: Main scope

Target information

Here you can find our YouTube channel where there are talks and quickstart guides for some of our products such as the SKS Managed Kubernetes.

All Exoscale zones are in scope of this program (some of the URLs below point to "ch-gva-2" as an example).

Access:

Credentials:

Upon joining the program, each researcher will get a mailbox auto-assigned to them. Each researcher will receive automatically an email with a list of coupons that can be used to register multiple accounts on Exoscale.

Each coupon can be used once to register an account using a different email addresses. You should register using the assigned Bugcrowd email alias using the + tag capabilities for multiple accounts. Ex: curious.badger+account1@bugcrowdninja.com

If you need more coupon codes, you can contact support@exoscale.com by providing your username and @bugcrowdninja.com email address.

Treasure Map

A treasure map that contains a detailed description of our product and infrastructure is available to program participants when requesting credentials. A list of our internally used domains and IPs is also provided and define the scope that can be scanned for vulnerability. Any other IPs in our AS ranges would belong to customers and be out of scope.

By joining the program, you agree not to disclose any of the provided information.

target_groups.name: Out of Scope
target_groups.description_html:
Out of scope

  • Customer infrastructure is out of scope
  • Failure to Invalidate Session issues
  • No Rate Limiting on Form issues unless the researcher can demonstrate a strong security impact
  • Vulnerabilities that only results in inconsequential losses for Exoscale (under USD 500, ex: resources or coupon limit bypass)
  • All P5 severity vulnerability as described on the Bugcrowd Vulnerability Taxonomy
  • Activities amounting to denial of services
  • Missing Secure or HTTPOnly Cookie Flag
  • Email Spoofing to Inbox due to Missing or Misconfigured DMARC on Email Domain
  • Vulnerabilities only affecting users of outdated or unpatched browsers
  • Software version disclosure
  • Very recent public vulnerability (patch available for less than 2 weeks)
  • Attacks that require unlikely user interaction

name: Sophos
tagline: Responsible disclosure with rewards up to US$50,000

target_groups.name: Windows Intercept X Premium Target
target_groups.description_html:
Sophos Endpoint Protection is a multi-component system where some parts run at the highest possible privilege. One of the design goals is to protect users of the endpoint from threats on the network, therefore remote compromise of Endpoint Protection components is of particular concern to Sophos.

Attacks meeting ALL of the following conditions are eligible for consideration of a maximum bounty of $50,000:

• triggering execution of attacker-controlled code
• in a high privilege context (Administrator or higher for Windows)
• doing so remotely
• doing so via Endpoint Protection components
• no user interaction is necessary

Clear instructions for how to reproduce the finding are required.

Some examples of in and out of scope scenarios follow. These are intended to illustrate the above definition, not to limit it. Attacks that meet the definition will be in scope.

Examples:

In-scope examples (all must lead to the attacker able to act as Admin, with no user interaction):
• Direct exploitation via an exposed port associated with an Endpoint Protection component.
• Target machine receives an email from attacker triggering RCE due to Endpoint Protection processing / parsing.
• A browser on the endpoint visits a webpage leading to code execution due to Endpoint Protection interactions with the browser or associated network traffic.

Out-of-scope examples:

  • Code execution after connecting via an authorized remote route, e.g. RDP. This is not considered a remote exploit since the RDP connection gives the attacker a presence local to the target.
  • Any attack where a user needs to enter credentials. Attacks where user interaction is required are excluded from this bounty target.
  • Any attack where code execution is obtained but not in the context of Admin.

All testing can be done with free trial versions https://www.sophos.com/en-us/products/endpoint-antivirus/free-trial of the product on the Windows platform.

IMPORTANT. All research should be done on fresh trial versions of Intercept X and when signing up for the trial, ensure your email has bugcrowdninja in the address. For example, tom+bugcrowdninja@gmail.com or bill@bugcrowdninja.com

Eligible findings are reproducible on fully patched installations of Intercept X. Sophos will not reward issues that are not reproducible in the latest release. Testing should be done on 64-bit Windows only, Windows 10 22H2 (build 19045) or later Windows 11 22H2 (build 22621) or later.

target_groups.name: XG Firewall Premium Target
target_groups.description_html:
Findings eligible for the highest payout are/come with:

  • Attack Vector: Network (WAN interface only)
  • Attack Complexity: Low (no MitM etc.)
  • Privileges Required: None (pre-auth only)
  • User Interaction: None (no phishing, etc.)
  • Impact: Code/command execution as root (CVSSv3+ C:H/I:H/A:H)
  • Reproducible on the latest maintenance release of the latest version, as published on MySophos
  • Detailed version information:
    • Login to the Device Console
    • At the console> prompt type: “system dia sh ver”
    • Add the output to the report (screenshots accepted)
  • PoC code or step by step reproduction instructions
    • May be in the form of a video
  • Tools used to detect the issue, if any
  • Information on what helped discover the issue most:
    • Root shell access
    • Reverse engineering (decompiled JARs)
    • Previously published CVE (incl. CVE ID)
    • Other (please elaborate) *Source code file and line of the issue, if possible

All testing can be done with free trial versions of the product on any available platform (software/virtual/hardware).

IMPORTANT. All research should be done on fresh trial versions and when signing up for the trial, ensure your email has bugcrowdninja in the address. For example, tom+bugcrowdninja@gmail.com or bill@bugcrowdninja.com

Eligible findings are reproducible on fully patched installations of XG Firewall (see https://community.sophos.com/kb/en-us/135415 for details). Sophos will not reward issues that are not reproducible in the latest release.

target_groups.name: Premium Bounty Eligible Targets
target_groups.description_html:
Eligible findings are/come with:

  • Reproducible on the latest maintenance release (MR) on an actively maintained product branch that is generally available (GA)
  • Detailed version information

All testing can be done with free trial versions of the product on any available platform (software/virtual/hardware/operating system).
